title: 112_s50
content: The Act is titled the "Commercial Seafood Consumer Protection Act" and includes provisions for the safety net of commercially marketed seafood consumers. The Commercial Seafood Consumer Protection Act mandates the Secretary of Commerce, in collaboration with other federal agencies, to enhance consumer protection for seafood quality and safety. This includes strengthening interagency agreements within 180 days to address seafood safety, labeling, and fraud. The Commercial Seafood Consumer Protection Act mandates the Secretary of Commerce to enhance consumer protection for seafood quality and safety through cooperative arrangements, coordination of inspections, standardizing data, and information sharing to detect violations. The Commercial Seafood Consumer Protection Act mandates the Secretary of Commerce to enhance consumer protection for seafood quality and safety through various measures such as expediting imports, tracking shipments, enhancing labeling requirements, and commissioning officers for enforcement. The Secretary of Commerce can commission officers to conduct seafood examinations, share information on non-compliance with seafood requirements, conduct joint training, and share relevant information related to importation and exportation. The Secretary of Commerce can commission officers to conduct seafood examinations, share information on non-compliance with seafood requirements, conduct joint training, and share relevant information related to importation and exportation. This includes outreach to private testing laboratories, seafood industries, and the public on Federal efforts to enhance seafood safety and compliance with labeling requirements. Annual reports on implementation of agreements are also required. The Secretary, the Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, and other relevant Federal agencies must submit an annual report to Congress on efforts to strengthen seafood safety, labeling, and prevent fraud. Additionally, a joint report on marketing, labeling, and fraud must be submitted within one year of the Act's enactment. The Federal Trade Commission and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration will submit a joint report to Congress on seafood fraud and deception in the US market, enforcement efforts, and ways to address unfair practices. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration will report deceptive seafood marketing and fraud to the Federal Trade Commission. This does not affect existing agreements on cooperation and information sharing in fish inspection between the Department of Commerce and the Department of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Commerce and the Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit a joint report to Congress on the implementation of agreements related to food safety. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration will coordinate the NOAA Seafood Inspection Program. The NOAA Seafood Inspection Program will work with the Sea Grant Program to provide outreach on seafood testing, labeling, and combating mislabeling and fraud. Within 180 days of this Act, the Secretary will increase certified laboratories for analyzing seafood to ensure compliance with FDA standards. The Secretary of Commerce will publish a list of certified laboratories within 1 year and update it annually. NOAA will also have its own laboratories. SEC. 4. NOAA LABORATORIES. The Secretary may increase laboratories' capacity for testing under this Act as necessary. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can refuse entry of seafood imports from a country if they don't meet federal requirements. Increased testing may be ordered for seafood imports from a country with potential law violations. Individual shipments may still be allowed from the exporting country. The Secretary may permit individual shipments of seafood from a country or exporter if they meet federal requirements and pass inspection. The Secretary can cancel an order for seafood exports from a country. The Secretary can allow seafood shipments from a country or exporter if they meet federal requirements. If an exporter fails to comply with an order, the 1-year period for compliance starts from the date of that determination. This section does not affect the authority of the Secretary of Health and Human Services under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act regarding seafood or other products. SEC. 6. INSPECTION TEAMS. The Secretary, in cooperation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, may send inspectors to foreign countries or exporters of seafood to assess practices related to farming, harvesting, and transportation. The inspection team will provide technical assistance on federal laws regarding seafood fraud and safety, prepare a report for the Secretary of Commerce, and allow the country or exporter 30 days to respond to the findings. The Secretary may send inspectors to foreign countries or exporters of seafood to assess practices. The exporter can provide a rebuttal to the findings. The report will be used by the Secretary of Health and Human Services for risk-based determinations and by the Federal Trade Commission for consumer protection recommendations. SEC. 7. SEAFOOD IDENTIFICATION. SEC. 7. SEAFOOD IDENTIFICATION. The Secretary and the Secretary of Health and Human Services will develop a standardized list of names for seafood to be used in distribution, marketing, and retail. The list will consider taxonomy, labeling regulations, international law, market value, and naming precedence to prevent consumer confusion. The list will be published on government websites, open for public review, and updated annually. The term "applicable laws and regulations" in this Act refers to Federal statutes, regulations, and international agreements related to seafood importation, exportation, transportation, sale, harvest, processing, or trade. It includes specific laws such as the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act and regulations like the Seafood Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point regulations. The term "appropriate Federal agencies" encompass entities like the Department of Health and Human Services and the Federal Food and Drug Administration. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Commerce.
